metadata.case_name: Appellants v. State of U.P. and Others

facts.text: U.P. Regulation of Building Operations Act 1958 received assent of President on October 8, 1958.
Notification issued on December 10, 1958 declaring Ghaziabad a regulated area under S. 3 of U.P. Regulation Act.
Controlling Authority under S. 4 of Regulation Act constituted in February 1959.
Notification under S. 4 of Land Acquisition Act issued on July 16, 1960 declaring intention to acquire about 34,000 acres in fifty villages of Ghaziabad for planned development.
Notification under Ss. 6 and 17 of Acquisition Act issued on December 23, 1961 for 19.75 acres.
Successive piecemeal notifications under S. 6 in 1962 and 1963.
Notification on February 9, 1962 under S. 4 modifying earlier notification, reducing area to 6158 acres.
Appellants applied on July 4, 1962 to Special Land Acquisition Officer for copy of scheme of planned development to make representations under S. 5A.

Special Land Acquisition Officer ordered: 'The scheme of the planned development is not necessary for a notification under S. 4 of the Act, as such, no such scheme of the planned development is available in this office.'
State Government sanctioned Master Plan of Ghaziabad under Regulation Act on September 4, 1962.
Writ petition filed by appellants on September 27, 1962 challenging notifications.
Batch of 39 writ petitions including appellants' allowed by High Court on December 10, 1965, quashing S. 6 notifications for piecemeal nature.
Another batch of writs allowed quashing S. 6 notifications on same ground.
Supreme Court in State of Madhya Pradesh v. Vishnu Prasad Sharma decided on February 9, 1966 that piecemeal S. 6 notifications not permissible.
Land Acquisition Amendment Validation Ordinance No. 1 of 1967 promulgated by President on February 20, 1967.
Appellants challenged Ordinance and notifications in High Court in February 1967.
Act passed in April 1967 on lines of Ordinance; challenged by amendment.
Supreme Court in Udai Ram Sharma v. Union of India upheld Acquisition Amending Act 1967.
High Court dismissed appellants' writ on March 26, 1968.
S. 4 notification dated July 16, 1960 stated land likely needed 'for planned development of the area'.
Writ petition paras 35(b), 36: No proper opportunity under S. 5A as notification vague, no indication of different uses/purposes.
Para 33 of petition: Different S. 6 notifications show no specific scheme at S. 4 stage, unclear who would use land.
Return para 9 to para 33: Scheme for planned development existed when S. 4 issued, though not finalized in details.
No reply in return to paras 35(b), 36 or to SLAO order.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notification under S. 4(1) stating public purpose as 'planned development of the area' was too vague, denying effective opportunity to object under S. 5A.
Validity of piecemeal notifications under S. 6 (already decided).
Validity of Land Acquisition Amendment Validation Act 1967.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification under S. 4 vague - 'planned development of the area' gives no indication of precise purposes (residential, industrial etc.), who develops (Govt or others), defeating S. 5A right.
No scheme or Master Plan provided or available at time; SLAO refused copy.

petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of MP v. Vishnu Prasad Sharma

respondent_arguments.text: Scheme for planned development existed at S. 4 stage, though not finalized in details.
Appellants had copy of Master Plan sanctioned Sept 4, 1962; matter of common knowledge, published in newspapers.
Planned development is public purpose under S. 3(f) as amended; sufficient.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act S. 3(f) U.P. Amendment 1954; Arnold Rodricks v. State of Maharashtra

respondent_arguments.text: Acquisition in pursuance of U.P. Regulation Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: U.P. Regulation of Building Operations Act 1958

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of LA Act requires S. 4(1) public purpose stated with particularity to enable survey under S. 4(2) and effective objections under S. 5A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Planned development of the area' too vague; no indication of residential/industrial etc. or who develops.

court_reasoning.text: S. 5A gives substantial right to object; must not be defeated by vague purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cited Nandeshwar Prasad: right under S. 5A cannot be taken away lightly.

court_reasoning.text: No proof appellants aware of or shown Master Plan at relevant time; rejected State's late evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dismissed amendment petition for additional evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Arnold Rodricks distinguished: there purpose specified as industrial/residential.
High Court repelled contentions based on earlier judgment; Amendment Act upheld per Udai Ram.

holdings.text: Vagueness of public purpose in S. 4 notification denies effective S. 5A opportunity; proceedings invalid.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh Others v. Vishnu Prasad Sharma Others
Udai Ram Sharma etc. v. Union of India Others
Nandeshwar Prasad Anr. v. The State of U.P. Others
precedents_cited.relevance: S. 5A right is substantial, cannot be taken away lightly.

precedents_cited.case_name: Arnold Rodricks Another v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Public purpose specified as industrial/residential sufficient; unlike vague 'planned development' here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Babu Barkya Thakur v. The State of Bombay Others
precedents_cited.relevance: For company acquisitions, S. 4 purpose less critical; not applicable here.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Notification under S. 4 must specify public purpose with particularity for effective S. 5A objections; vagueness invalidates.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Regulation of Building Operations Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Ghaziabad declared regulated area; Controlling Authority constituted; Master Plan sanctioned.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition (U.P. Amendment) Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Expanded 'public purpose' to include planned development.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; entire acquisition proceedings in respect of appellants' lands quashed due to vagueness in S. 4 notifications denying S. 5A rights. No laches found. Costs to appellants.
outcome.relief_granted: Quashing of acquisition proceedings; costs in Supreme Court.
outcome.costs: Appellants entitled to costs in this Court.

key_quotes.text: 'The scheme of the planned development is not necessary for a notification under S. 4 of the Act, as such, no such scheme of the planned development is available in this office.'
key_quotes.speaker: Special Land Acquisition Officer
key_quotes.significance: Shows no scheme available, supporting vagueness claim.

key_quotes.text: Owing to the vagueness and indefiniteness of the public purpose stated in the notifications under S. 4(1) ... the appellants were wholly unable to object effectively and exercise their right under S. 5A.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Section 5A embodies a very just and wholesome principle that a person whose property is being ... acquired should have a proper and reasonable opportunity of persuading the authorities concerned.
key_quotes.speaker: court
